results.abstract: US Apollo 16 launched on Apr 16 with Saturn 5 rocket into earth orbit; after 11/2 orbits, Saturn's 3d stage is retired, sending spacecraft out of earth orbit and toward moon at 24,500 mph; Comdr Mattingly steers command ship into nose-to-nose linkup with lunar module; insulation material begins peeling off lunar module; astronauts are never in danger but cause of problem remains mystery; NASA officials rept there are no holes or fuel leaks in module; either problem would have forced cancellation of lunar landing; NASA officials speculate that command ship control thruster may have been fired excessively or at skewed angle, scorching metallicized plastic covering on attached lunar module and producing peeling; flight controllers are continuing to study situation; spacecraft is launched under clear skies, Cape Kennedy; scientists are hoping that data gathered by astronauts will resolve debate over whether moon ever had hot and active interior; expect to learn more about moon's chem and physical properties; after separation from lunar module, Saturn's 3d stage is fired toward moon; it should crash on moon before lunar landing occurs; lunar module is covered with Mylar insulation for thermal protection and has thin aluminum covering for protection against micrometeorite impacts; top of module is also painted for additional protection against intense solar heat on lunar surface; area where problem occurred covered tanks supplying fuel for maneuvering rockets; at first, it was feared that one of tanks had sprung leak, perhaps from vibrations during launch or during linkup between lunar module and command ship; such a leak would have precluded landing attempt since maneuvering rockets are used to stabilize lunar module as it approaches moon and on return from lunar surface when it achieves rendezvous with command module; earlier, Young and Duke inspected lunar module and reptd finding no major malfunctions; illus of 3 astronauts and Apollo 16 launch

results.abstract: exhaustive tests on ground on Apr 20 find that malfunction in US Apollo 16 command ship's secondary guidance system is not serious enough to abort planned lunar landing; Mattingly detects problem while making checklist to ascertain whether command ship engine can be fired safely; engine, which has bell-shaped nozzle, is mounted on 2 gimbals that allow it to swivel to certain degree to insure that engine thrust is properly aligned; inability of command ship to circularize lunar orbit is significant because many of scientific and photo experiments must be conducted from circularized altitudes; crew depends on main rocket engine to fire spacecraft out of lunar orbit and back toward earth; astronaut Capt Cernan duplicates procedures that led to problem in command ship simulator, Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston; engineers hold slight oscillations in rocket engine were caused by circuit trouble in backup guidance system and motor-driven mechanisms that move gimbals

results.abstract: US Apollo 16 astronauts Young, Duke and Mattingly are drinking substantial quantities of potassium-spiked orange juice in effort to prevent heartbeat irregularities and other serious med problems; potassium and other electrolytes are essential in balancing delicate biochemical reactions that regulate body's internal environment; Dr Berry says he prescribed liquid because potassium injections are impractical and could be dangerous for astronauts in space; astronauts are unhappy about potassium requirement; Berry says weightlessness exacts physiologic cost by forcing astronauts to lose potassium in urine as result of complicated series of reflexes involving their hearts, brains, adrenal glands and kidneys

headline.main: Crew Sipping Potassium Drink To Bar Heartbeat Irregularities

byline.original: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMANSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, April 24 -- The Apollo 16 astronauts, to their obvious distaste but to their better health, are gulping gallons of a potassium-spiked orange drink -- just as are millions of earth-bound humans who are benefiting from major advances in medical physiology that have taken place since World War II.

results.abstract: 3-min firing of US Apollo 16 spacecraft's main rocket engine on Apr 24 boosts craft out of lunar orbit and back toward earth; Duke and Mattingly take pictures of receding moon and of earth rise from spacecraft windows; spacecraft is traveling at 2,300 mph; during final hrs of lunar orbit, astronauts release 85-lb satellite that is expected to remain in lunar orbit and return scientific data for about 1 yr; instruments are designed to measure moon's gravitational and magnetic fields and to study 'solar wind'; astronauts jettison lunar module, which begins tumbling out of control because of malfunction in small maneuvering rockets; flight controllers cancel plans to crash module on lunar surface so that resulting shock waves can be measured by seismometer left on moon by Young and Duke; such measurements help scientists learn more about moon's interior; flight dir P C Shaffer says Young and Duke apparently failed to close circuit-breaker in lunar module's control system when they were shutting down vehicle prior to jettison maneuver; holds module's guidance computer instructions were unable to reach maneuvering rockets because of open circuit-breaker; says 2 astronauts may have overlooked switch setting because they were working hurriedly, with heavily revised list of tasks; revisions were necessary because of many changes in flight plan after lunar landing was delayed for 6 hrs; Duke apologizes to Mission Control for oversight; Young holds moon may have stopped changing after its 1st 500-million yrs of existence; astronauts spend most of day stowing equipment, cleaning cabin and preparing for firing of main rocket engine; astronauts are forced to curtail some of scientific experiments; Mattingly repts he has completed nearly all of orbital photography
